Monica long a registered nurse with no
history of illness had a suspicious
mammogram after a biopsy
four words got her doctor's attention on
the pathology report ductal carcinoma in
situ or DCIS is the earliest stage of

found it very early my cancer and the

of the breast then I just prayed for the
best never dawned on me that they could
have been a mistake but her new doctor
says that her cancer diagnosis was wrong
this confusion has become increasingly
common as pathologists help doctors
diagnose breast cancer at an earlier
more survivable stage with advanced
imaging tests thirty years ago most
women were diagnosed with breast cancer
when they felt a lump disease was
already palpable and DCIS can be
identified by screening mammography when
the patient is totally unaware of any
abnormality in her breast so that's the
goal to make a diagnosis before the
disease is even invasive that's where
the difficulty comes as the field has
gotten more complex the potential for
mistakes has grown now pathologists
whose job is to work in a lab rather
than see patients diagnosed cancer using

of a few grains of salt so time has
changed and they will give you an orange

if you're dealing with you know five

wide variation of skill and experience
with these microscopic lesions has led
to misdiagnosis errors are particularly
common with cases of low grade DCIS when

eight years ago Aguilar had a needle

and she said well mastectomy

she took her slides to the pathology

something different

he used a free consultation from another

this problem will lead to an increase in
